Appendix:
For more information on NanoString GeoMx technology visit [**our website**](https://www.nanostring.com/products/geomx-digital-spatial-profiler/geomx-dsp-overview/).

Details of the performance of WTA have been [**published**](https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.09.29.462442).

Minerva is an open-source software package that was developed by Laboratory of Systems Pharmacology at Harvard University and is available [**here**](https://github.com/labsyspharm/minerva-story/wiki).

We would like to thank Jeremy Muhlich and John Thomas Hoffer for assistance in enabling Minerva features to support the Spatial Organ Atlas.

Sources:

Rashid R, Chen, YA, Hoffer J, Muhlich JL, Lin JR, Krueger R, Pfister H, Mitchell R, Santagata S, Sorger PK. (2021) Narrative online guides for the interpretation of digital-pathology images and tissue-atlas data. *Nature Biomedical Engineering*, p1-12 [https://doi.org/10.1038/s41551-021-00789-8](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41551-021-00789-8)

Hoffer J, Rashid R, Muhlich JL, Chen, YA, Russell D, Ruokonen J, Krueger R, Pfister H, Santagata S, Sorger PK. (2020). Minerva: a light-weight, narrative image browser for multiplexed tissue images. Journal of Open Source Software, 5(54), 2579, [https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.02579](https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.02579)

Illustrations by Dave Carlson/[CarlsonStockArt.com](https://www.carlsonstockart.com/)

FOR RESEARCH USE ONLY. Not for use in diagnostic procedures.

Stories.Description:
Welcome to the [**Spatial Organ Atlas (SOA)**](https://www.nanostring.com/spatial-organ-atlas) Colon Demonstration.

The SOA is a database for whole transcriptome spatial profiles of functional components of tissues from human and mouse generated with the GeoMx® Digital Spatial Profiler. All the data in the SOA is downloadable, including [**this colon sample (#001)**](https://www.nanostring.com/products/geomx-digital-spatial-profiler/spatial-organ-atlas/human-colon/).

Using [**Minerva**](https://github.com/labsyspharm/minerva-story/wiki), we will show you how the imaging and molecular data combine to give you a comprehensive profile of the tissue architecture and biology.

Click around to explore on your own. 

Hints:
* Zoom and pan the image via the mouse/trackpad.
* Open and close the left- and right-hand menus by clicking on < or >.
* See results in the left-hand menu and click on the selectable regions to zoom to the featured area of the tissue.
* Turn channels on and off with the right-hand menu.
* The colon image has a very broad dynamic range. On some monitors, at lower magnifications, some detail may not be visible. We recommend raising brightness and possibly adjusting contrast.
* There is a small area on the right-hand side of the image with no fields of view captured by the imaging software as it was identified as blank space.

Waypoints.Name: Gross Colon Anatomy
Waypoints.Description:
The main function of the colon is to remove water, nutrients, and electrolytes from partially digested food, thus concentrating stool prior to defecation. To support this function, the colon has four main layers: mucosa, submucosa, muscularis externa, and serosa.

The mucosal layer is a smooth surface punctuated by crypts. It is divided into three main parts: the epithelium, the lamina propria, and the muscularis mucosae. In the epithelial layer, enterocytes act as a barrier separating the lumen of the colon from the colon tissue, enteroendocrine cells absorb water and produce hormones and peptides, and goblet cells secrete mucus. Beneath these, the lamina propria is a layer of connective tissue which helps maintain the integrity of the mucosa, and contains many immune cells including plasma cells, lymphocytes, macrophages, granulocytes, and mast cells. The bottom of the mucosal layer is the muscularis mucosae, a thin layer of smooth muscle tissue.

Surrounding the mucosal layer, the submucosa contains connective tissue, nerves, blood vessels and collagen fibers that help maintain the shape of the colon. The submucosa also contains colonic patches, which are lymphoid follicles that regulate immune homeostasis in the context of the colonic microbiome and food-derived antigens. The colonic patches are organized into B cell-containing germinal centers and T cell zones to regulate T and B cell activation and function. Surrounding the submucosa is the muscularis externa, which consists of circular and longitudinal muscles that help move digested food through the colon. Finally, the serosa is a loose connective tissue outside of the muscularis externa which prevents damage from friction as the colon moves.

This colon tissue was visualized with antibodies to PanCK (epithelial cells), CD45 (​immune cells), 5-HT (enteroendocrine cells including Paneth cells) and SYTO83 (nuclei).
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* If you select the square on the image above, a region containing the colon wall is highlighted on the image to enable orientation.
* If select the colonic patch, three representative colonic patches are highlighted on the image.
* You can toggle the Regions of Interest (ROIs) that were molecularly profiled by clicking on the respective data layers (left-hand side of screen).
* You can change the morphology markers being displayed by selecting channel groups – all markers or individual markers can be displayed. Switching to an individual marker can make it easier to see small ROIs.
* The “All data layers” category allows you to toggle between selecting all data layers and selecting no data layers. A single click can unselect all data layers, allowing easy selection of a single data layer (If any layers are unselected, the first click will select all layers, the second click will unselect all).

Waypoints.Name: Detailed Colon Anatomy
Waypoints.Description:
With GeoMx DSP, Regions of Interest (ROIs) are selected by the user and then molecularly profiled. These ROIs can be either profiled whole (i.e., geometric profiling) or subdivided based on the visible morphology markers into compartments and profiled separately (i.e., segmented profiling).
In the cartoon below, the key features of the colon are highlighted with red outlines and shading. Selecting these features will show a typical ROI on the tissue image.
1. Colonic patch: Geometric
2. Epithelium: (PanCK+, CD45-) segmented
3. Lamina propria: (PanCK-, CD45+) segmented
4. Enteroendocrine cells: (5-HT+) segmented
5. Muscularis mucosae: Geometric
6. Vessels: Geometric
7. Submucosa connective tissues: Geometric
8. Circular muscle layer: Geometric
9. Longitudinal muscle layer: Geometric
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Select the epithelium on the diagram above. (Note: with this ROI, you are looking down on the epithelium, and the crypts appear as circular structures.) Toggle on and off the epithelium and lamina propria data layers to see the segmentation possible with GeoMx DSP. Selecting the CD45 channel may make it easier to see segmentation.
* The enteroendocrine cells are very small segments, demonstrating the fine control of the GeoMx optical system. Using 5-HT, multiple small regions are selected within a single ROI, only a few microns across. Selecting the Nuclei channel may make the segments easier to see. Selecting the 5-HT channel and toggling the enteroendocrine cells on and off shows the precision of selection.

Waypoints.Name: Linking Molecular and Imaging Data
Waypoints.Description: One of the key aspects of spatial biology is the ability to link molecular and spatial (image) data. In this figure, the average number of genes detected per ROI by structure is shown. Select a data point within the box plot to see its corresponding ROI. As expected, ROIs with few cells (e.g., vessels and connective tissues) have fewer genes detected than ROIs with a large number of transcriptionally active cells (e.g., colonic patches).
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints: 
* Select a single data point to be taken to that ROI.
* If you hover your mouse over the boxplot, a summary of the distribution metrics for that ROI type will be displayed.

Waypoints.Name: Cell Type Deconvolution
Waypoints.Description:
Here, we are measuring the relative abundance of different cell types within each ROI using a [**cell type deconvolution algorithm**](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-022-28020-5). For this colon data, the cell types are as defined by the [**Gut Cell Atlas**](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-021-03852-1). In this graph, each column is a single ROI, and each structure has a unique composition of cell types. By comparing the cellular composition of different ROI types, we can learn about the biological activity within the colon. For example, IgA-producing plasma cells were observed in the lamina propria where their antibodies can be secreted into the lumen of the intestine. The naïve and memory B cells are co-localized along with T cells and antigen-presenting cells, where they can maintain long-lasting immunity and respond to novel pathogens.

The enteroendocrine and epithelial ROIs demonstrate the power of enrichment by segmentation. The enteroendocrine cells (EECs) are hormone-producing cells that regulate nutrient absorption and are found in the epithelium. They were profiled in the geometric epithelium ROIs, but since the transcriptional profile is averaged from many cell types in the epithelium, the enteroendocrine cell signature is reduced. By contrast, a subset of EECs express 5-HT, which was used as a morphology marker to define the EEC compartment, so the transcriptional profile of those ROIs consists almost entirely of EECs.
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint: 
* Select a column of the figure to be taken to the corresponding ROI in the image.

Waypoints.Name: Spatial Mapping of Gene Pathways
Waypoints.Description:
Whole transcriptome profiling allows us to spatially map functional gene pathways and gene sets, as well as individual genes. This heatmap of single sample gene set enrichment analysis (ssGSEA) shows relative expression of various gene sets in different ROIs. Three tissue-specific sets of genes are highlighted.

The muscle-associated groups (longitudinal, circular, and muscularis mucosae) have a set of enriched genes that include gene sets for cardiac muscle contraction, tropomyosins and vascular smooth muscle contraction. The colonic patch and lamina propria share a set of enriched immune genes (LAG3, Primary Immunodeficiency genes, Cell Adhesion Molecules), but have distinct patterns of expression for other immune genes and adhesion molecules (TIGIT, SELE, E-cadherin). The epithelium has clear epithelial gene sets (exosomal proteins of epithelial cells and the epithelial sodium channel genes), but also shows the presence of the immune genes commensurate with its role in interacting with the microbiome.
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Click on a column to see the specific ROI the data applies to.

Waypoints.Name: Differential Gene Expression
Waypoints.Description:
Lamina Propria vs Lymphoid Structures

Spatially resolving whole transcriptome data allows us to understand how cells work within the context of their tissue environment. For example, we see that many genes associated with B cell homing (CCL19, CCL21, and CXCL13) and maturation (MS4A1/CD20 and BLK) are expressed in the lymphoid structures, which are the site of B cell homing, activation, and maturation. The lamina propria is where B cells (now matured into plasma cells) secrete antibodies that protect the colon against microbes and thus play an important role in maintaining gut homeostasis. We can see evidence of this antibody-associated gene expression in the lamina propria by enrichment of IGHA1, JCHAIN, IGLL5, and IGKC.
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Select the regions on the graph with the genes that are differentially expressed (in blue and light blue) to see all the ROIs where they are more highly expressed. Turning on only the Nuclei channel may help you see smaller ROIs.

Waypoints.Name: Validating Gene Expression with Protein Expression 1
Waypoints.Description:
We explored the relationship between our data and the [**Human Protein Atlas**](https://www.proteinatlas.org/) to see if the gene expression patterns we observed would also be detected at the protein level. As seen in the immunohistochemistry image below from the Human Protein Atlas, *CHGA* (the gene encoding Chromogranin A) is very specifically expressed in enteroendocrine cells. CHGA is a precursor for three biologically active peptides, pancreastatin, vasostatin, and parastatin, which act as negative regulators of the neuroendocrine system.

![image](img/CHGA_colon.png)

[*Image credit: Human Protein Atlas.*](https://images.proteinatlas.org/40544/84847_A_8_3.jpg)
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Select an individual point on the graph to be taken to that ROI in the image.
* If you hover your mouse over the boxplot, a summary of the distribution metrics for that ROI type will be displayed.

Waypoints.Name: Validating Gene Expression with Protein Expression 2
Waypoints.Description:
Next we looked at the expression of the *PIGR* gene which encodes polymeric immunoglobulin receptor. This mediates IgA and IgM transcytosis across mucosal epithelial cells into intestinal lumen. The [**Human Protein Atlas**](https://www.proteinatlas.org/) immunochemistry image below shows the expression of PIGR by epithelial cells.

When we review GeoMx expression data from different colon regions, this gene is strongly expressed only in epithelial and enteroendocrine cells.

![image](img/PIGR_colon.png)

[*Image credit: Human Protein Atlas.*](https://images.proteinatlas.org/12012/28150_A_9_3.jpg)
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Select an individual point on the graph to be taken to that ROI in the image.
* If you hover your mouse over the boxplot, a summary of the distribution metrics for that ROI type will be displayed.
